etymologies: mid 17th century; earliest use found in Henry More (1614–1687), philosopher, poet, and theologian. From post-classical Latin arrogativus from classical Latin arrogāt-, past participial stem of arrogāre + -īvus

definitions: Characterized by arrogation; that arrogates (also with of).

notes.text: Apparently not recorded between the late 17th and early 20th centuries.
